awd_titl_txt: Structural Learning and Statistical Inference for Large-Scale Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims at developing new structure learning and statistical inference procedures for capturing some essential structures of large-scale data, emerging from scientific studies in genetics, biology, neuroscience, finance, and meteorology, among others. New tools for stochastic modeling, computational algorithms, and statistical inference applied to multi-channel brain EEG recordings, multi-subject fMRI and multiple neuron spike trains in neuroscience research, and identifying structural changes in climate data and copy number variation in genetics, will be developed. Outcomes of this study will help scientists to efficiently analyze large-scale imaging, temporal and spatial data, and thus will have broader impacts on our society through their direct impacts on these applications to science, public health, and information technology. Dissemination of these developments will enhance new knowledge discoveries, and strengthen interdisciplinary collaborations. The research will also be integrated with educational practice through designing either regular, seminar or short courses on new statistical approaches for analyzing complex data as well as benefitting the training and learning of undergraduate, graduate students and underrepresented minorities.

This research work focuses on statistical learning of fundamentally distinct types of structures, with the ultimate goal of better understanding of complex systems. Motivated from inferring neural connectivity from the ensemble neural spike train data, Project 1 will learn the directed acyclic graph structure in a large Poisson network, underlying a wide array of multivariate point process data. The related probabilistic mechanism will provide new insights into understanding statistical properties of the estimators for graph parameters relevant to mining the causal relation among neurons. Inspired by feature extraction and source separation from multi-channel brain EEG recordings and non-linear temporal signal processing, Project 2 will develop a class of non-linear non-smooth combinations of structured component analysis (SCA) to extract hidden component signals from observed mixed signals. The SCA developed will be more broadly applicable in scientific studies. Motivated from identifying and understanding structural changes in climate trends, and structural variation in gene copy numbers associated with genetic diseases, Project 3 will develop a novel two-step adaptive procedure of jump detection, for simultaneously selecting the unknown number of jump points and detecting their locations in the flexible non-parametric regression model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The DMS-2013486 ("Structure learning and statistical inference for large-scale data," 2020/08/15-2023/07/31) funding supports 19 journal and conference papers (accepted, under review, or in revision). Other research products include computer packages and related software using Matlab and R scripts in the papers, updated on the GitHub repositories of the PI or coauthors. Computer packages for published papers have been posted on the journal websites and the PI's homepage at UW-Madison, openly shared with the broader community.

Intellectual merit: This proposal aims to develop new structure learning and statistical inference procedures to capture essential structures within large-scale data arising from scientific studies in genetics, biology, neuroscience, finance, meteorology, analytical chemistry, and other fields.

  1. [1] Zhang, Zhu, and Shen (2023, Machine Learning) explore the suitability of 'robust-BD' for sparse large-dimensional regression models with incompletely specified response variable distributions and propose a new estimate called the 'penalized robust-BD estimate' that achieves the same oracle property as ordinary non-robust penalized least-squares and penalized-likelihood estimates. They conducted extensive numerical experiments to evaluate the performance of the proposed penalized robust-BD estimate and compared it with classical approaches, showing that our proposed method improves on existing approaches in the presence of outliers. The proposed approach is not straightforward and presents several challenges, but it offers provable results that contribute to advancing the field.
  2. [2] Zhang, Ye, and Wang (2023, International Statistical Review) developed fast and effective approaches to visualize the feasibility of projection pursuit (PP) in extracting informative features from high-dimensional data, compared to methods like Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Independent Component Analysis (ICA). They also assessed the plausibility of PP in cases where asymptotic studies are lacking, aiming to understand the practicality, limitations, and challenges of using PP for large data analysis.
  3. [3] Motivated by the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) study, Shen, Park, Chakraborty, and Zhang (2023, The New England Journal of Statistics in Data Science) have developed the Bayesian simultaneous partial envelope model. This novel model is supported by theoretical results, comprehensive simulations, and a real imaging genetics data application specifically tailored to the ADNI study.
  4. [4] In longitudinal studies, the analysis of asynchronous longitudinal data, where responses and covariates are measured at different times, can be challenging. Zhong, Zhang, and Zhang (2023, Statistica Sinica) introduced a locally sparse estimator of the GVCM within the framework of functional data analysis. The asynchronicity issue is addressed using the kernel method. The sparsity of the coefficient function is achieved through the imposition of a sparseness penalty. They also established theoretical properties of the proposed method.
  5. [5] For supervised classification, Wu and Zhang (2023, Journal of Data Science) conducted extensive numerical studies to compare the performance of the Penalized Discriminant Analysis (PDA) index with the Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) index and Support Vector Machine (SVM) for classifying high-dimension low sample size data, demonstrating that the PDA index is robust to outliers and able to handle high-dimensional datasets with extremely small sample sizes, few important variables, and multiple classes.
  6. [6] Jia, Zhang, and Lu (2022, Journal of Multivariate Analysis) compare the performance of the proposed regularized-covariance-function-based estimator and the conventional high-dimensional covariance matrix estimator of the within-subject errors when the number of time points per subject exceeds the number of subjects.

Broader impacts: Results developed in the project have the potential to be used broadly in many applications and will have broader impacts on our society. The project also contributes to educational activities. For example, Zhang (2021, The American Statistician) provides further examples related to correlation coefficients between variables and ranks, emphasizing the need for a more relevant interpretation of ranks in sharing information about data. The derivations presented are easy to follow, making them accessible to advanced undergraduate and beginning graduate students. These examples are beneficial for gaining additional insights into and a better understanding of the flexibility and limitations of ranks used in nonparametric statistics. During 2020-2023, four Ph.D. students out of six PhD. students defended their dissertations under the PI's guidance on topics related to the project. Since 2020, the PI has been sponsoring and training 8 (including 3 females) undergraduate students for research internships; through the PI's training and mentoring, three undergraduate students who had a strong interest in research participated in research projects and a training practice project (Wu and Zhang, 2023, Journal of Data Science, led by a female student) as co-authors.
